Understanding Project Structure

An application project is a way of grouping together all the items associated with a particular endeavor. Most frequently, this endeavor is a software application created by your company or a component of that application.

A project may include views, folders, files, change requests, requirements, tasks, topics, and audit log entries. It resides on a single server and server configuration.

When a project is first created, it has an initial or root view. However, over time, any number of child views may be derived from that view.

The application uses views to:

  • Provide access to a subset of the files in a project. For example, a developer may not need to see the project files used for marketing purposes, while a market researcher might not need to see the source code files. With this application, both can work on the same project in different views, each of which is a subset of the root view. Such views are called reference views.

  • Provide a branch for the project. For example, suppose the root (or initial) view of a project stores source code for Release 1.0 of a software application. After the application is released, your company plans to work on Release 2.0 in the root view. Therefore, it creates a branch view for work on a maintenance release (e.g., Release 1.0 Service Pack 1). Because the branch has a different view, it allows files with the same names to contain different code. The application allows you to merge such files when required.

All views, whether they are a root view or a child view, have a single application folder as a root folder. However, a root folder can contain a hierarchy of child folders.

When you create a project, its root view and root folder are created automatically and given the same name as the project. You can change these names at any time, if you have the appropriate access rights.

Each application folder has a corresponding working folder on your workstation – that is, a location to which files are checked out. You can set up your working folders to form a hierarchy similar to that of the application folder hierarchy or to have different paths.
